Award.AwardTitle: BP: Computer Science for the Social Good: Using Near-Peers to Engage Latino/a Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
ETR Associates will design and test a near-peer strategy, called CSteach, for infusing Computer Science (CS) content and the connection between CS and the social good into K-12 technology programming curriculum. Effective strategies for engaging Latino/a students in computer science (CS) require an increased focus on the societal implications of computing. CSteach employs a multigenerational approach where trained high school students (near-peers) facilitate a weekly afterschool class where they provide instruction and role modeling to 5th grade students. The goals are to create a sustainable and scalable network that will increase the interest and capacity of Latino/a students to pursue computer science. Intended outcomes include increased knowledge and support systems of 5th grade and high school students to pursue computer science classes and careers. External evaluation will monitor project progress toward these goals and assess changes in students? and teachers? knowledge and attitudes. The project builds on the exemplary practices of the Watsonville TEC program, the Computing Alliance for Hispanic Serving Institutions, and the Global Information Internship Program at UC Santa Cruz.

CSteach will contribute to our understanding of the teaching and learning of computing K-12 students. The scalable curriculum and training materials produced as a result of this project will help leverage Latino students' existing interest in computing. The program will be culturally relevant, but the advanced computing concepts and connection to the social good will be applicable to other groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is growing concensus that in order to increase diversity in computer science (CS) majors and the workforce, we need to inspire and educate students about CS starting in elementary school. In addition, access to quality CS education experiences in K-12 has become a social justice imperative. However, there is very little research on what is a developmentally appropriate approach to introducing and reinforcing CS concepts at such a young age, and how to frame those concepts in terms that are familiar and connected to students' everyday experiences.

The goal of this project was to create a culturally responsive, sustainable, and scalable program that increases Latino/a students' interest, intention, and capacity to pursue additional computer science classes. To this end, we created Computing for the Social Good, an after school class where students and teachers learn about CS and social justice principles, and how they are connected. It employs a multigenerational approach where trained high school students (near-peers) provide instruction, build relationships, and serve as role models to 5th grade students. The class teaches and reinforces developmentally appropriate concepts in CS and social justice, and weaves them throughout the 13 sessions. These include big ideas in Computer Science (Abstraction, Algorithms, Programming, and Networks) and in Social Justice (Fairness and Equity, Community, Empowerment, and Action).

Over the three years of this project, there were 394 elementary school students and 31 high school students involved. Results of an external evaluation suggest that elementary school students reported higher levels of computational skills and gained greater CS knowledge, compared to students in an afterschool technology class that did not have near-peers or a social justice focus. There was some variation among subgroups: students from Spanish-dominant households were less confident in their computing abilities at the beginning of the semester, yet made greater gains over the semester than students from English-dominant households. And girls demonstrated greater CS knowledge than boys. In addition, students with high attendance had statistically significant increases in self-efficacy for computing, and in their perceived ability to use computing to address community needs compared to students with absences.

The high school aged near-peers also showed substantial growth in their expectation that they could perform certain computational tasks, such as programming a computer, using abstraction to design a project, and using computer networks to share work. They made greater gains in computer science understandings and skills than in other areas, such as using a computer to change society. The near-peers also demonstrated moderate growth in CS identity, especially their beliefs that they know what a computer scientist does and that computer scientists are cool.

Broader Impacts: The results of this study can inform other efforts to teach computer science concepts to elementary school students, particularly those from households with low levels of education and limited opportunities to learn about or engage in the practice of computer science. The project has also begun to generate findings that will inform efforts to integrate a social justice perspective into CS education classes for youth. It has also resulted in a detailed curriculum and tip sheet about near-peers that will be disseminated to educators, and several peer-reviewed publications.
